events.name: Android on x86 platforms & Second-Screen API demo
events.description:
Xavier Hallade from Intel will demonstrate that x86 architecture can’t be avoided on the app market as it offers strong performances to complex applications. He will then demo the use of the 2nd-Screen API on +Android app with the Wireless Display.

Please register on http://android-on-x86.eventbrite.com/?aff=meetupcom

events.name: Dart Flight School
events.description:
Dart hit 1.0 and is now Flight Ready! Developer communities around the world are hosting Dart Flight School events during the month of February 2014.

Join us for an evening with Chris Buckett (Dart expert) and Pete Bacon Darwin (Angular expert) to learn Dart and Angular, build modern web apps with a new language, core libraries, and tools such as a package manager, editor. Use Angular with Dart for extra jet fuel, as Angular has ported their popular framework to Dart which will be covered in great detail with tutorials and coding examples.

Register on http://dart-flight-school-london.eventbrite.com/?aff=meetupcom

events.name: Running Node.js on Google Cloud Platform
events.description: Arun Nagarajan is a Tech Lead for Google's Developer Platform and will talk us through and demo deploying Node.js projects to Google Cloud Platform. Google recently announced Managed VMs, that help developers combine the power of App Engine and Compute Engine to deploy easy-to-manage custom runtimes of their choice.

events.name: Build the future with Polymer!
events.description:
We’re going to kick off with some quick talks on +Polymer, what Polymer is doing to create an end-to-end workflow for developers and their users, unveil the burgeoning ecosystem of web components, and demonstrate the next generation of web apps. We’ll then dive into building out elements and apps in your choice of codelabs or free-for-all hacking, with help from +Eric Bidelman and  +Addy Osmani

The web components revolution is here. Join us in building the future!

Don't forget to register on the Evenbrite page where you can also find more details about the event:

http://polymer-london.eventbrite.com/?aff=meetup
events.how_to_find_us: Go to the Campus reception and say the event name, the'll send you to the 3rd floor

events.name: DevFest London 2014
events.description:
Devfest will be 2 days full of talks, fun and networking on Saturday 15th Nov, workshops on Sunday (will be announced separately). Both days will be held in Campus London

See more details including speakers line-up on the Devfest website - http://devfest.gdg-london.com and get your own spot for Saturday until they’re all gone:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/devfest-london-2014-registration-13372023081?aff=gdgmeetup

Make sure you’re registered on Eventbrite, that’s the only platform we use for tickets. Registering here on Meetup does NOT guarantee you place. This event will mainly be used for communication with our Meetup community.

events.name: Introduction to Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
Description
=========
This session provides a brief introduction to Google Cloud Platform services including App Engine, Compute Engine, Cloud Storage and BigQuery where we also discuss the advantages of using these services and what makes Google Cloud Platform great for developers.

Speaker
======
Nawaid Shamim is a Google Developer Expert (GDE) for Google Cloud Platform and a System Engineer at Sony Computer Entertainment where is architects, develop and maintain web services for various Playstation games. He has a Bachelor’s degree in Computer Science and a Masters degree in Computer & Network Security. He is currently based in London. He advocates and evangelize for cloud computing and has great interest in distributed systems, machine learning and automation.

Registration
=========
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/introduction-to-google-cloud-platform-tickets-15822216676?aff=meetupcom

events.name: Building Realtime Apps With Firebase & Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
Full description & registration:
http://building-apps-with-firebase-and-google-cloud.eventbrite.com/?aff=meetupcom

Talks
====
1) Building Realtime Apps With Firebase by Sara Robinson & Mike McDonald
Realtime is becoming an essential part of any user experience. Previously, making an app realtime has been difficult to achieve and requires many engineers. In this talk, Sara will explain how you can use Firebase's realtime API to store and sync data instantly without wiring up a backend. At the end of the talk, Sara will risk it all by live coding and deploying an app with Firebase!

2) Building responsive Web apps with Go, Polymer and Google Cloud Platform by Mandy Waite
The Go programming Language continues to gain momentum amongst developers and is becoming extremely popular on Google App Engine. In this session will show how you can use the App Engine Go Cloud endpoints library to build from scratch, a service that exposes backend application functionality via a RESTful API running on the Google API infrastructure used to run Google's own APIs. We'll then look at how you can design and build a responsive frontend application that consumes this newly created API using Polymer and Web Components. We will also demonstrate how we used Web Components to build an interactive frontend for an existing Go application, the Kubernetes Container Cluster scheduler.

3) Big Data Analytics using Google BigQuery by Nawaid Shamim
Every action in today’s digital world generate a lot of data which can be essential in making important business decisions but dealing with massive datasets can be challenging. Traditional tools might not scale as the dataset continually grows. Storage requirements can grow as fast as the dataset, so downloading data to your computer's hard drive is no longer a workable approach. And it can take a long time to retrieve the right subsets of data from a traditional database query.
In this session, we will analyze Big Data in the cloud with Google’s BigQuery by running fast, SQL-like queries against multi-terabyte datasets in seconds. BigQuery enables you to build the real-time data-analysis solutions you need now, while being confident that you can scale your solutions in the future.

events.name: Deterministic Behaviour and Performance in Trading Systems
events.description:
Registration & full description:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/deterministic-behaviour-and-performance-in-trading-systems-tickets-15865560318?aff=meetupcom

Talk
====
One way to model a complex event driven system is as a series of functions or state machines with the data inputs and a data output. Recording and replaying data for such state machines can help testing these systems for reliable behaviour in terms of data output and timings. It can also make restarting and upgrading a running system easier. This talk will look at how this approach is applied in high frequency trading systems. Speaker:
======
Peter Lawrey, currently CEO of Higher Frequency Trading Ltd, previously working for Barclays, RBS, Sun and a few other companies.

He likes to inspire developers to improve the craftmanship of their solutions, engineer their systems for simplicity and performance, and enjoy their work more by being creative and innovative.

events.name: Deep dive into Google Cloud Storage
events.description:
Agenda:

18:30 - 18:45  Registration
18:45 - 20:00  Tech Talk

About:

In the cloud computing world we have more choice than ever before of where to put our data and how to access it -- each option with different costs, optimal access patterns, and APIs for reading and writing our data, both big and small.

In this session, we'll walk through the menu of storage options inside GCP (and some of their equivalents on AWS and Azure), and how to choose the right one for you.
We'll look at Cloud Datastore in depth and see how you can use it from your Node JS application. We'll also explore how to integrate Firebase into sample app to add some real-time features. By the end of the session, you should have a good working knowledge of the various storage options out there, and some deep knowledge about Cloud Datastore specifically.

Speaker:

JJ Geewax, Software Engineer at Google

Based in New York, JJ is a Software Engineer at Google working on Google Cloud Platform. While an undergrad at UPenn, JJ joined four other students starting a company called Invite Media as a software engineer, and eventually became responsible for coordinating all of the company's engineering efforts. A few years later (2010), Invite Media was acquired by Google, and Invite became Google's largest "cloud customer" -- first on Amazon, and later on GCP.

Please register on https://goo.gl/bQ2Uer

events.name: Getting started with Kubernetes and scaling clusters declaratively
events.description:
About:

We’ve all written an application from scratch before. You start with some code on your laptop and tell a server to run it. You make tweaks, update manually, and realize that you’ve committed yourself to a very imperative process. It’s manual. Inefficient. What’s worse, it’s completely unreproducible.

So then you might turn to Docker, which solves the process-level reproducibility by packaging up a full execution environment. But once we get beyond a single machine, we need to coordinate the work across a cluster of machines -- trying to do it imperatively can quickly turn into a tangled mess! You want to declare to your cluster what you expect it to do, and have the cluster assign the resources to get it done, recover from failures, and scale easily. 

Kubernetes is a recently open sourced cluster manager and scheduler that simplifies the complex tasks of deploying and managing your application. You simply declare the desired state, and Kubernetes does the work to keep it that way. In this talk, we’ll do a hands-on demonstration of how you can move from a single Docker container to many containers running across a cluster of machines by using Kubernetes.

Speaker:

Nawaid Shamim is a Google Developer Expert (GDE) for Google Cloud Platform and a Systems Engineer at Sony Computer Entertainment where is architects, develop and maintain web services for various Playstation games. He has a Bachelor’s degree in Computer Science and a Masters degree in Computer & Network Security. He is currently based in London. He advocates and evangelize for cloud computing and has great interest in distributed systems, machine learning and automation.

Please RSVP and register here - https://goo.gl/YiHr4K

events.name: Building infrastructure with Terraform
events.description:
Building your infrastructure as one-off thing by clicking in the UI of your chosen cloud provider may be easy, but that isn't scalable nor fun in long-term nor in team. We are going to dive into better & maintainable ways of building the infrastructure using Terraform's DSL.

Terraform is a tool for building, changing, and versioning infrastructure safely and efficiently. Terraform can manage existing and popular service providers as well as custom in-house solutions.

During the talk there will be demos covering basic and more advanced use of Terraform + Google-provider related usage. We'll also discuss the future of cloud provisioning relevant to Terraform & other available tools.

Speaker

Talking & demoing will be Radek Simko, one of the core committers to the Terraform project.

Venue

WeWork is the platform for creators. WeWork provides the space, community and services you need to create your life’s work. To learn more about WeWork's upcoming locations in London, send an email to [masked] and let them know you were referred by GDG London.

events.name: Chrome Dev Summit Extended
events.description:
Chrome Developer Summit

The Chrome Developer Summit is the pinnacle event of the year for Chrome, where web developers learn about the newest and latest trends and features for the upcoming year. Join Google at Skillsmatter in London for our VIP partner round table, watch the live stream, hear from Google Developer Expert Dean Hume and mingle with other kindred spirits over drinks afterwards.

The live stream will kick off at 4pm so make sure to arrive nice and early to get a good seat. 

And thanks to our wonderful sponsors - Google and CodeNode/Skillmatter.

Please register here, Meetup RSVP will not guarantee a place.

Contact [masked] if you have any questions.

events.name: Cluster management at Google with Borg
events.description:
Cluster management at Google with Borg

Cluster management is the set of tools and processes that Google uses to control the computing infrastructure in our data centers. It includes allocating resources to different applications on our fleet of computers, looking after software installations and hardware, monitoring, and many other things. I'll provide an overview of what we can do, and explain how the lessons we've learned have driven the design of Kubernetes, our new open-source cluster management system. We certainly don't have all the answers, but we do have some pretty impressive systems.

John Wilkes 

Principal Software Engineer, Technical Infrastructure, Google. John Wilkes has been at Google since 2008, where he is working on cluster management for Google's compute infrastructure; he was one of the architects of Omega. He is interested in far too many aspects of distributed systems, but a recurring theme has been technologies that allow systems to manage themselves. You can also see his publications here

Please register here, Meetup RSVP will not guarantee a place and please arrive by 18:45 as the actual talk will start at 18:45.

Contact [masked] if you have any questions.

events.name: Code The Road
events.description:
Code The Road

What: We're hitting the road for a series of Google Maps APIs hosted events. We’ll have talks from Google engineers, product managers, customers and partners building with the Google Maps APIs as well as drinks and snacks. Space is limited but we’re doing our best to accommodate as many people as possible.

Why: Maps have transformed the way we use technology. They connect us, elevate our curiosity, and give us freedom to explore, share and access what’s around us. Google Maps has been at the forefront of bringing simple, useful, and comprehensive maps to billions of users. But it’s developers who are the real force behind today’s massive adoption of maps.

We'd like to meet the people who are building new maps and location-enabled experiences.

Who Should Attend? Developers, product managers and technical leads building iOS, Android, or web apps.

For registration and more information about schedule, speakers please visit their official website here. Please note Meetup RSVP will not guarantee a place.

Contact [masked] if you have any questions.

events.name: GDG DevFest London 2015
events.description:
GDG DevFest London 2015

The biggest Google tech conference in London carefully crafted for you by GDG community! All about Android, Web and Cloud from the world experts

THINK OUT OF THE BOX. CREATE WHAT YOU WANT!

More info - http://devfest.gdg-london.com/

Please register here, Meetup RSVP will not guarantee a place.


fans.start() - Saving on heating bills with WebGL by David Li
A trip through real-time graphics programming using WebGL through in-depth technical breakdowns of various demos, featuring massive particle systems, volumetric rendering, fluid dynamics simulations, and more.

Asynchronous Data Streams in Angular 2 by Gerand Sans
Angular 2 introduces a new Data Architecture based on Reactive Programming. We are really excited to see the new approach using Observable sequences aka Observables. Besides, the new HTTP module was released only a month ago! We will cover a basic introduction of Angular 2 followed by streams and the new HTTP API covering some basic use cases.

Why Google Cloud Platform is the cloud for you by Grace Mollison
Google Cloud Platform is a world class platform for running all sorts of applications. In this session learn about the philosophy behind Google Cloud Platform and why it is 'the' platform for running your application. Google is a company that has been delivering internet scale solutions like search, Gmail etc for years and are always looking at ways to make developers more productive. This Session will explain how by using Google Cloud Platform you can become as productive as Google developers.

Give your users superpowers in the real world by Hoi Lam
People no longer need to sit at a desk to get the benefits of technology. You can now build experiences that work seamlessly between the digital world and the real world. Superpowers that would not have been possible, too complex or prohibitively expensive are now possible. Join this session for the latest update from Google on the platform components now available.

Hooked on HTTP/2: Building services with gRPC by Mandy Waite
gRPC is a language-neutral, platform-neutral RPC framework and toolset which is based on the finalized HTTP/2 standard and developed and open sourced by Google. It can be used to build highly performant, scalable APIs by allowing developers to define services using a powerful binary serialization toolset and language called Protocol Buffers. It can also be used to generate idiomatic client and server stubs from service definitions written in a variety of languages. In this session you’ll learn all about gRPC and how it benefits from being based on HTTP/2 and through the use of a working demo and detailed code examples you’ll learn how to build gRPC enabled microservices and clients.

Progressive Web Apps and Push Notifications by Peter Beverloo
There have historically been significant differences between native apps and the Mobile Web in regards to performance, capabilities and user expectations. On Android, Web apps live in the browser, while native apps are everywhere. In this session you will learn about Progressive Web Apps, Push Notifications and other recent changes in Chrome that enable you to deliver rich and integrated experiences that delight your users.

Building for the next billion users by Sam Dutton
The next billion users who are coming online for the first time aren’t restricted to any particular region: they’re in the Americas, EMEA, and APAC. As developers, we want to build for everyone — and we need to make sure the 'next billion users' can rely on our products and services. In this session you will learn how to design apps and sites for any context where connectivity is flakey, bandwidth is limited, or data is prohibitively expensive.

What’s my car thinking? - A different type of mobile computing by Steven Gray
We have all heard in the news of the rise of car manufacturers lying to drivers about their car's performance, but what happens if you own an old car? Do you even have or use a car in London? If not then you might not care. Anyway, come and find out how I used an Android phone, an embedded bluetooth sensor, Google Maps and a whole load of Google Cloud Services to figure out what was happening under the hood. Plus, for an extra bonus, we will go into detail of some the Easter Eggs and features that now available in Google Maps App as well as some other fun things you might not know about Google Maps. You'll never look at a Google map the same way again!

And thanks to our wonderful sponsors - Google and CodeNode/Skillmatter.

Please register here, Meetup RSVP will not guarantee a place.

Contact [masked] if you have any questions.

events.name: Android Study Jam
events.description:
What are Study Jams

Google Developers Study Jams is a free series of global, community-run, in-person study groups. The current Study Jams series is presented in partnership with Udacity and will follow their Android for Beginners curriculum:

https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

Please also register here:

https://skillsmatter.com/meetups/7930-android-workshop

Week 1: https://plus.google.com/events/cdkomit79gtq05qn9diiuebue0c

Week 2: https://plus.google.com/events/cbkht1u2h9entluq8tvf5v5squk

Week 3: https://plus.google.com/events/cgu1rts539net0tdk1ffopghfdg

Who is it for

The Study Jams for Android for Beginners is best suited for two audiences those new to programming or those with programming experience who have never used Android.

Google+ community for students

Students may join a public Google+ community to meet other Study Jam participants and discuss questions, share apps, etc.

https://plus.google.com/communities/107779414017676143474

We'll be meeting once a week (on Thursdays) for 3 weeks: 17, 24 and 31 March.

More info about Android Study Jams:

http://developerstudyjams.com

</a>

<a href="http://developerstudyjams.com/">

events.name: GDG DevFest London 2016
events.description:
GDG DevFest London 2016

One of the biggest Google tech conferences in London carefully crafted for you by GDG community!

DevFest will focus on Android, Web and Cloud from some of the world's leading experts. We've got a great range of speakers from Google and beyond. Join us to learn, share ideas and have fun!

Register today (it's free!): http://gdg-devfest-london-2016.eventbrite.com/?aff=meetup. Meetup RSVP will not get you into the event.

Web Track:

Intro to AMP (Accelerated Mobile Pages) by Boris Farber

Putting the P in Progressive Web Apps by Sam Thorogood

Migrate To Progressive Web Apps by Sam Thorogood

Thinking Offline by Phil Nash

The Amazing Angular 2 Router by Gerard Sans

Android Track:

Developing Media Streaming Apps for TV the Easiest Way by Mario Viviani

ClassyShark - APK analysis with ClassyShark by Boris Farber

Firebase Overview by Luiz Gustavo Martins

A beginners guide to machine learning for mobile developers by Sharif Salah

Android is for one user by Ataul Munim

Cloud Track:

Building Node.js Applications on GCP by Mandy WaiteTensorFlow for Poets codelab by Nick Birnie & Sharif Salah

Improve your App UX with one model processing insights from logs (batch) and real-time activity streams by Robert Kubis

Hackathon demoLearning Go - Build your first Slack app using Go and App Engine by Ernesto Jiménez

Thanks a lot to our awesome sponsors - Google and Campus London!

events.name: Google Hash Code 2017
events.description:
Hash Code is a team-based programming competition for university students and industry professionals across Europe, Middle East and Africa. Teams will be tasked with solving algorithmic problems that are inspired by real challenges that people face at Google (previous problems here). In February there will be an Online Qualification Round, and the top scoring teams from this round will then be invited to the Google Paris office to compete in the final round of the competition in April. Are you up for the challenge? ;)

The competition is divided into two stages:

• Online Qualification Round on 23rd February

• Final Round (at Google Paris) on 1st April

For the Online Qualification Round, we are encouraging you to join us at the GDG London hub to compete side-by-side in a more fun environment.

Registration to compete in Google Hash Code 2017 is mandatory!  Follow the steps: 

1. Sign up at https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/.

2. Create a new team at https://hashcodejudge.withgoogle.com/ or join one of the existing teams using the invitation link.

3. Select the GDG London hub. You should see the following info on your team page:

A big thanks to our supporters and sponsors!

https://skillsmatter.com/about-us

https://developers.google.com/

events.name: Android Tech Talks in April
events.description:
In April, we’re partnering with MyDrive Solutions to bring you our next GDG London event at Skills Matter. Join us for an evening of learning, networking, and fun at the Android Tech Talks in April. At this event, you’ll have the opportunity to hear from Kaan Mamikoglu, James Coggan and Pascal How, mobile software engineers at MyDrive Solutions, a Generali company. Kaan will talk about why you should use Firebase Analytics in your Android applications and what are the best practices. Pascal will focus on a great way of making API calls in Android applications using Retrofit. Then James will add on top of Pascal’s talk and explain how to store data you received from Retrofit using Realm Mobile Database.

_________________________________________________________________________
6:00 - Registration, drinks & pizza
6:45 - Firebase: A Great Analytics Service for Android Development - Kaan Mamikoglu
7:15 - Using the Retrofit for API Calls in Android Development - Pascal How
7:45 - Break
8:00 - Using the Realm Mobile Database in Android Development - James Coggan
8:30 - Networking

_________________________________________________________________________

Thanks to our venue sponsor - Skills Matter!

Please sign up at: https://skillsmatter.com/meetups/9249-google-developers-group-april-meetup

events.name: GDG DevFest London 2017
events.description:
Learn the latest in web, mobile, cloud, machine learning and more at the UK's largest community organised free conference.   To RSVP, go here >> https://goo.gl/LfLJiT.


GDG London, Google and UCL present >> GDG Devfest London - a multi-track event covering:

- cloud and machine learning
- mobile
- web
- tech entrepreneurship
- codelabs
- demos

To find out more about speakers, topics and agenda, visit >> devfest.gdg.london

Don’t miss out on a fun, interesting and informative day of expert speakers, demo stands,  coding labs and much much more.

You’ll also get the chance to network with experts from Google, UCL and beyond and learn more from some of the amazing developer communities we have in London.

There will be people taking photographs and potentially filming the event. By attending you agree to the possibility of being photographed and filmed once inside the venue.

Thank you for your interest in GDG DevFest London and we look forward to seeing you there.

See you on Saturday, November 11!

Again, to RSVP, go here >> https://goo.gl/LfLJiT.

events.name: January Android Meetup (with Londroid)
events.description:
We're kicking off 2018 with Android Things. In January, we're partnering with Londroid as they're bringing you Deliveroo Londroid event. Join us on 17th of January at the Deliveroo office.

Please register at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/deliveroo-londroid-tickets-41695703973 where you can also find the event details.

We'll be giving away an Android Things kit as well as a 1-year individual subscription for a JetBrains Toolbox product.

• Important to know
Eventbrite registrations will open on January 4th at 10am and an Eventbrite ticket is required to attend the event.

events.name: Android Things Workshop Day 1

venue.name: MyDrive Solutions
venue.address_1: Unit 1.2.01 - The Leathermarket Weston Street, SE1 3ER · London

events.description:
Android Things gives you the ability to connect all your IoT devices! You can write Android Things code the same way you write your current Android apps using Kotlin or Java in the way you're familiar with.

In these workshops you will have several sensors, IoT devices and Android Things kits available to you. We'll spend some time with a short introduction to Android Things and initial setup. After that, you will have some guidelines to follow on how to integrate your favorite IoT or Cloud tool using Android Things.

You will need to bring your own laptop and charger. If you have an Android Things kit or a Raspberry Pi 3 board, feel free to bring it so that more people can benefit the kits we have!

You'll have chance to work on one of the following:

• Firebase and Android Things

• Using the inputs and outputs of the rainbow hat on Android Things

• Connect your phone and Android Things with Google’s Nearby

• Integrating the Philips Hue with your Android Things

• Connect your Arduino and Android Things

• Reading data from sensors and sending data to actuators using Android Things

We'll start with some food and drinks at 6pm and continue with the codelabs at 6:30pm.

Important: This is the first part of a series of 2 workshops! Register for the other workshop at https://www.meetup.com/gdglondon/events/246888344

events.name: Android Things Workshop Day 2

venue.name: MyDrive Solutions
venue.address_1: Unit 1.2.01 - The Leathermarket Weston Street, SE1 3ER · London

events.description:
Android Things gives you the ability to connect all your IoT devices! You can write Android Things code the same way you write your current Android apps using Kotlin or Java in the way you're familiar with.

In these workshops you will have several sensors, IoT devices and Android Things kits available to you. We'll spend some time with a short introduction to Android Things and initial setup. After that, you will have some guidelines to follow on how to integrate your favorite IoT or Cloud tool using Android Things.

You will need to bring your own laptop and charger. If you have an Android Things kit or a Raspberry Pi 3 board, feel free to bring it so that more people can benefit the kits we have!

You'll have chance to work on one of the following:

• Firebase and Android Things

• Using the inputs and outputs of the rainbow hat on Android Things

• Connect your phone and Android Things with Google’s Nearby

• Integrating the Philips Hue with your Android Things

• Connect your Arduino and Android Things

• Reading data from sensors and sending data to actuators using Android Things

We'll start with some food and drinks at 6pm and continue with the codelabs at 6:30pm.

Important: This is the second part of a series of 2 workshops! Register for the first workshop at https://www.meetup.com/gdglondon/events/246888390

events.name: Google Hash Code 2018
events.description:
• What we'll do
Hash Code is a team-based programming competition for university students and industry professionals across Europe, Middle East and Africa. Teams will be tasked with solving algorithmic problems that are inspired by real challenges that people face at Google. In March there will be an Online Qualification Round, and the top scoring teams from this round will then be invited to the Google Dublin office to compete in the final round of the competition in April. Are you up for the challenge? :wink:

The competition is divided into two stages:

• Online Qualification Round on 1st March

• Final Round (at Google Dublin) on 28th April

For the Online Qualification Round, we are encouraging you to join us at the GDG London hub to compete side-by-side in a more fun environment.

Registration to compete in Google Hash Code 2017 is MANDATORY! Follow the steps:

1. Sign up at https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/ .

2. Create a new team at https://hashcodejudge.withgoogle.com/ or join one of the existing teams using the invitation link.

3. Select the GDG London hub.

events.name: GDG London April - Kotlin meetup
events.description:
This months, we're organising a Kotlin meetup at The App Business office.

Schedule :
18:30 - 19:00 Welcome & Networking
19:00 - 19:40 Talk 1 - Kotlin Coroutines: make your world more synchronous
19:40 - 19:50 Break
19:50 - 20:30 Talk 2 - The State of Kotlin
20:30 - 21:30 Networking

Kotlin Coroutines: make your world more synchronous
In this talk we’ll have an introduction to the coroutines in Kotlin. We’ll see how they work, what we can do with them and how they can help us in making our code look more synchronous and easier to manage. We’ll also briefly discuss about the interaction with existing code and we’ll take a look at some of the “crazy” things that such a powerful tool allows us to do. The talk will be mainly focused on Android, but many of the concepts could probably be useful also in other platforms where Kotlin coroutines are available.

Speaker : Andrea Bresolin - Android Engineer at The App Business (TAB)

The State of Kotlin
Over the last three months I ran a survey of the global Kotlin ecosystem. My goal was to learn how developers use and adopt Kotlin - either in work or side projects, or just for playing around, and what are some of the most popular resources for learning it.

The survey was a great success, and gained over 2400 responses in total! The results are meant to become a resource for the Kotlin community. Something we can all look at for interesting insights that will also help drive adoption of Kotlin in our teams and organisations.

To give you a taster, here’s a few questions I asked in the survey:
- How big is Android as a proportion of all Kotlin developers
- Are people happy naming libraries and tooling with K
- What are the favourite features of the language
- What kind of DSLs are people building with Kotlin and for what use-cases
In my talk will answer all these questions, and more. But be warned, some answers might surprise you.

Speaker : Zan Markan - Developer Evangelist @Pusher

events.name: Google I/O Recap - Lightning Talks
events.description:
Come join us for the Google I/O Recap lightning talks! We’ll cover all the exciting announcements and news from the Google I/O 2018 developer conference.

Agenda:
6 - 6:10 Welcome & intros
6:10 - 6:30 PM What’s new in Android - Busra
6:30 - 6:50 PM What’s new in Google Assistant - Aygul
6:50 - 7:20 PM Pizza & drinks time
7:20 - 7:40 PM What’s new in Firebase - Kaan
7:40 - 8:00 PM Google I/O Tips & Tricks (1 slide each)

All Google I/O attendees from this and previous years are invited to contribute their tips - we’ll compile all slides into one presentation beforehand.

If you’ve attended Google I/O in the past and would like to share any tip with other attendees, please send your 1-slide lightning talk (around 2-3 min.) via Meetup.com or to [masked].

events.name: Build Actions for Your Community (BAFYC): Actions on Google Talks
events.description:
Build Actions for Your Community (BAFYC) is a global community event series designed by Google and brought to you by Google Developer Group (GDG) London! Come join us to learn how to build Actions for the Google Assistant that are useful for your community - whether it's a professional network, interest group, or your hometown.

Tentative schedule:
6 - 6:10 Welcome & intros
6:10 - 6:40 PM Building Conversational Experiences with Actions on Google - Sebastian Mauer (Google UK)
6:40 - 7:00 PM Pizza & drinks
7:00 - 7:30 PM Steven Gray - TBA (GDE Assistant)
7:30 - 8 PM 10 Things Every Google Assistant App Should Do - Aygul Zagidullina (GDG/WTM London)

We'd like to thank Skills Matter for hosting this event! Please make sure to RSVP on their event page at https://skillsmatter.com/meetups/11069-build-actions-for-your-community-bafyc-actions-on-google-talks. Thank you and see you all there!

events.name: Build Actions For Your Community - Workshop
events.description:
Details

Build Actions for Your Community (BAFYC) is a global community event series designed by Google and brought to you by Google Developer Group (GDG) London!

Come join us to learn to create an amazing app for the Google Assistant, see live app demos from your peers and network with Google Assistant experts. The codelab will be instructor led.

Build Actions for the Google Assistant (Level 1): https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/actions-1/index.html

Mentors: Aygul Zagidullina (https://twitter.com/aygul) , James Coggan (https://twitter.com/mad_team), Jaroslaw Ankowski (https://twitter.com/jarekankowski), Kaan Mamikoglu (https://twitter.com/kaanmamikoglu)

events.name: GDG London - Flutter meetup
events.description:
Schedule :
06:30 : Welcome & Pizzas & Drinks
07:00 - 07:35 : Andrea Bizzotto - InheritedWidget is your friend!
07:35 - 07:40 : Break
07:40 - 08:20 : Swav Kulinski (GDE on Flutter) - Flutter: Talking to the business
08:20 - Networking

Talk #1 : InheritedWidget is your friend!
On this talk we explore three different ways of getting access to dependencies in Flutter, and their tradeoffs.
First, we’ll take a look at global state as an easy way of getting the things we need. Then, we’ll talk about constructor dependency injection, what problems it solves, but also which new ones it introduces.
Finally, we will learn how to make use of InheritedWidget and how it can help as you scale up your apps. I’ll show a simple app as a example of how these techniques work in practice.

Speaker : Andrea Bizzotto

Talk #2 : Flutter: Talking to the business

GIVEN I am a Flutter Developer
AND there are plenty of mobile frameworks
WHEN talking to the business about a new project
THEN I have convinced them to use Flutter

Speaker : Swav Kulinski - GDE on Flutter

events.name: Android & Firebase Security Talks
events.description:
Our female participants are welcome to register here: https://www.meetup.com/Women-Techmakers-London/events/253942788/. Due to a very high demand from our male community member, we're opening a limited number of spots for them. Thank you for your interest and feedback!
- -
Google takes security very seriously, but security is a journey, not a milestone, so there’s always much to be done to keep ecosystem secure. We at GDG London are really excited to invite you all to the Android & Firebase Security Talks, Women Techmakers (WTM) Edition, hosted by Google at their King's Cross office (6PS). Our speakers will share more about some of the interesting and difficult problems Google is working on day-to-day, the progress they made, and how Google’s tools for Android and Firebase can make users more secure.

Agenda:
6 - 6:10 PM Welcome & intros
6:10 - 6:50 PM Malware Flavours: Exploits - Elena Petrova (Google UK)
6:50 - 7:20 PM Fire Safety: Secure Your Firebase Data - Kaan Mamikoglu (GDG London)
7:20 - 7:50 PM Pizza & drinks
7:50 - 8:30 PM Security and User Perception - Raissa De Guzman (Google UK)

events.name: Flutter Study Jams - Session 1
events.description:
Flutter Study Jams are Community-run study groups based on the Flutter Udacity Course. Participants learn how to use Flutter to develop high-quality, interactive mobile applications for iOS and Android devices.

-Why?
Study Jams are a great opportunity to bring members of your community together to learn Flutter in person and support them to complete the course. Everyone, who completes the course will get a Google-offered Study Jam completion certificate and a profile badge.

-Who?
Flutter Study Jam is suited best for: 1) those just getting started with mobile app development 2) those with programming experience on other mobile app frameworks.

events.name: Flutter Study Jams - Session 2
events.description:

events.name: GDG DevFest London 2018

venue.name: Imperial College London
venue.address_1: Hide Map Imperial College London SW7 2AZ London, United Kingdom

events.description:
Learn the latest in web, mobile, cloud, machine learning, assistant and more at the UK's largest community organised free conference.

TO REGISTER FOR THE EVENT - go to >> https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/gdg-devfest-london-2018-tickets-50723931645

GDG London, Google and Imperial College DocSoc (Department of Computing Society) present GDG Devfest London - a multi-track event covering:

- cloud and machine learning
- web
- mobile
- assistant
- codelabs
- demos

To find out more about speakers, topics and agenda, visit >> http://devfest.gdg.london

Don’t miss out on a fun, interesting and informative day of expert speakers, demo stands coding labs and much much more.

You’ll also get the chance to network with experts from Google, Imperial College and beyond and learn more from some of the amazing developer communities we have in London.

There will be people taking photographs and potentially filming the event. By attending you agree to the possibility of being photographed and filmed once inside the venue.

Thank you for your interest in GDG DevFest London and we look forward to seeing you there on December 1st!

TO REGISTER FOR THE EVENT - go to >> https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/gdg-devfest-london-2018-tickets-50723931645

events.name: Google Hash Code 2019
events.description:
Google Hash Code is back! You've had a year to sharpen up your coding skills and now is the time to put them to the test. Are you up for the challenge?

Hash Code is a team-based programming competition for university students and industry professionals across Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA). Teams will be tasked with solving algorithmic problems that are inspired by real challenges that people face at Google. In March there'll be an Online Qualification Round, and the top scoring teams from this round will then be invited to the Google Dublin office to compete in the final round of the competition in April.

The competition is divided into two stages:

• Online Qualification Round on 28 February
• Final Round (at an international Google office) on 27 April

For the Online Qualification Round, we're encouraging you to join us at the GDG London hub to compete side-by-side in a more fun environment.

Registration to compete in Google Hash Code 2019 is MANDATORY! Follow the steps:
1. Sign up here — https://codingcompetitions.withgoogle.com/hashcode
2. Create a new team or join one of the existing teams using the invitation link.
3. Select the GDG London hub

Join us on May 7th from 4:30 pm for a live streaming of the I/O keynote, cool demos, codelabs, food & drinks, swag and networking with London Developer Communities.

Please note that places are limited and will be allocated on a first come first served basis so register early to avoid disappointment.

events.name: Google I/O Recap - Lightning Talks
events.description:
Come join us for the Google I/O 2019 Recap lightning talks! We’ll cover all the exciting announcements and news from the Google I/O 2019 developer conference, behind the scenes insights (such as sandbox demos or codelabs), and share some useful tips and tricks from our past experience attending this top-notch developer conference.

Our speakers include Aygul Zagidullina (What's New in Google Assistant), James Milner (What's New in Web), Jason Berryman (What's New in Google Cloud), Kaan Mamikoglu (What's New in Android), Steven Gray (What's New in Google Maps), Swav Kulinski (What's New in Flutter), and more!

If you’ve attended Google I/O in the past and would like to share any tip with other attendees, please send your 1-slide lightning talk (around 2-3 min.) via Meetup.com. We’ll compile all slides into one presentation beforehand.

organizers.name: Aygul Z.
organizers.bio: GDE for Google Assistant. GDG & WTM London lead. Director @ MotaWord. Ex-@Google @Todoist. PhD Quantum Chemistry. Google Launchpad mentor. Google Product Expert.

group_profile.intro: Community Management & Support @Todoist. Ex-@Google. Early adopter. Technology admirer. Language geek. World traveler. Want to know more? Just google me! ;)
Ex-VP Citigroup. Chairman of Social Developers London. Director of Women Who Code London. Co-organizer of OpenTechSchool London, London API, Swift London and London Game Developers.
